Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Market Impact Identification of Dyadic Attribution Model for Disposition Assessment Using Online Games
Award.AbstractNarration:
Both public and private agencies have a need to identify psychological attributes that can lead to potentially undesired behavior or best-fit in the organization. Communities across the US and throughout the world are looking for new approaches to protect against
potentially dangerous behaviors. Cyber threats specific to our military, privacy, personal safety, financial security, and national security are initiated by human factors. Language used reveals the tendency of a user's behavior, which provides a window into the potential stability, dependability, and trustworthiness of an individual. The ability to identify potentially harmful human behavior before it is acted out becomes increasingly viable. The need for increased intervention measures by appropriate authorities before undesired behavior surfaces must be addressed. By measuring trustworthiness, organizational insider threats can be mitigated. By screening military personnel, stress-related disorders can be identified early on. By understanding students' disposition, cyber-bullying behavior can be recognized in order to safeguard students. By paying attention to the disposition of law enforcement personnel, community interactions can be less contentious and more effective. This I-Corps team has developed a methodology to identify threatening human disposition and deceptive motivation through analysis of online communication behavior


This technology has the ability to extract actors' language-action features based on their online communication to establish dyadic attribution models of trustworthiness. During interactive game playing, the technology analyzes online actors' choices based on their online conversations, to discern their communicative intent. The language-action features will feed a causality reasoning system where
the trustworthiness of the social actor is analyzed and updated in a recursive Bayesian inference framework. The analysis from this dyadic attribution model has the potential for assessing threatening human disposition and intent (e.g., disgruntled) based on information behavior. The further utilization of this model is to apply in similar instances such as identifying actors with tendencies for suicide, murder,rage, and violence based on their online behavior. With this product, the authorities can analyze psychological stability and respond when necessary to provide counseling so that tragic consequences can

POR.DRECONTENT:
We all want privacy, and yet business entities need to protect their intellectual property—and governments have an obligation to protect the populace and the social infrastructure from potentially malicious activities. Communities across the US and throughout the world are looking for new approaches to cybersecurity. There are no easy answers, but there is research to suggest that these issues will eventually be resolved by technology.

Threats specific to our military, personal safety, privacy, law enforcement, and national security are typically initiated by human factors. Humans express themselves in a wide variety of ways, and these expressions often contain overt intended messages, as well as covert unintentional messages. Especially when communicating online, the subtleties of communication can reveal the tendencies of an actor’s behavior, which provides a window into the potential stability, dependability, and trustworthiness of an individual. Our ability to identify potentially harmful behavior based on online users’ communication is becoming increasingly viable. Increased intervention measures by appropriate authorities before undesired behavior surfaces must be addressed whenever possible.

Originally, information security was all about perimeter access control. Firewalls were developed and Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) were created. But now everything is migrating to the cloud, and there are no boundaries. Now it’s all about granular access control and user permissions. And this highlights the problem of insider threats, because in the cloud there is no difference between insider threats and external threats. Any systematic approach to protecting against this new category of threats must model human factors to detect intrusions as well as inappropriate behaviors on the part of trusted insiders.

The FSU I-CORPS project with iSensor Analytics team is working to create a next-generation intrusion detection system (IDS) that analyzes behavior anomalies in a causal reasoning system that has been in development for 7 years. This causality reasoning system infers trustworthiness of interacting actors based on their language-action features in an online environment. The technology has the ability to extract actors’ language-action cues based on their online communication to establish dyadic attribution models of trustworthiness that can be used to identify potentially malicious behavior. Patterns of behavior are translated from language-action features.

Language-action features feed the causality reasoning system where the trustworthiness of the social actor is analyzed and updated in a recursive Bayesian inference framework. The analysis from this dyadic attribution model has the potential for assessing threatening human disposition and intent based on information behavior. Using data metric analysis of anomalous behaviors, this technology can make sense of communication patterns that reflect human intent. Although generally imperceptible to human analysis, our research has proven that there are patterns of trustworthy behavior that can be recognized, just as there are patterns of deceptive behavior that can be recognized. Analysis of these patterns can be codified and programmed into a system that will process and extract subtle dispositional characteristics to derive outlier behavior.  

The research data to support this effort is collected from web-based interactive online games that emulate real-world scenarios in real-time. (http://isensoranalytics.com)

What did we do?

We performed over 100 interviews with market players to validate the value proposition of the technology and the pain points of potential customers. In this way, we were able to uncover the market potential for the product, which we think is significant but elusive due to limited funding.

We identified a variety of market segments, and considered several distribution channels. We pushed the envelope to address the needs of markets that were peripheral to our initial marker segment, although we did not stretch our discovery process into these secondary markets. We maintained the focus of our discovery process by limiting it to the original focus of cybersecurity protection.

We re-engineered the business model for the technology under development, and reached out to venture capitalists to seek investment. In general, we found VC’s to be interested but cautious, as our model was complicated—did not fit well into an elevator pitch. In addition, the inner workings of the technology could not be revealed so as to protect intellectual property.

We held long discussions with potential clients and investors to identify a path forward, and the additional resources necessary to expand market viability. We met with programming consultants to scope out the effort required to complete a beta version of an automated next-generation intrusion detection system (IDS) that analyzes behavior anomalies to protect against outside attackers as well as insider threats. We met with legal counsel to scope out the limits of what we could and could not share with potential investors. We engaged with business development mentors and business technology owners to build conceptual infrastructure for next steps.

We continue to focus on the ongoing research in anticipation of new milestones that will allow us to renew our efforts to create a business model upon the foundation of this critical research.


Last Modified: 02/12/2017
Modified by: Shuyuan M Ho
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We all want privacy, and yet business entities need to protect their intellectual property—and governments have an obligation to protect the populace and the social infrastructure from potentially malicious activities. Communities across the US and throughout the world are looking for new approaches to cybersecurity. There are no easy answers, but there is research to suggest that these issues will eventually be resolved by technology. Threats specific to our military, personal safety, privacy, law enforcement, and national security are typically initiated by human factors. Humans express themselves in a wide variety of ways, and these expressions often contain overt intended messages, as well as covert unintentional messages. Especially when communicating online, the subtleties of communication can reveal the tendencies of an actor?s behavior, which provides a window into the potential stability, dependability, and trustworthiness of an individual. Our ability to identify potentially harmful behavior based on online users? communication is becoming increasingly viable. Increased intervention measures by appropriate authorities before undesired behavior surfaces must be addressed whenever possible. Originally, information security was all about perimeter access control. Firewalls were developed and Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) were created. But now everything is migrating to the cloud, and there are no boundaries. Now it?s all about granular access control and user permissions. And this highlights the problem of insider threats, because in the cloud there is no difference between insider threats and external threats. Any systematic approach to protecting against this new category of threats must model human factors to detect intrusions as well as inappropriate behaviors on the part of trusted insiders. The FSU I-CORPS project with iSensor Analytics team is working to create a next-generation intrusion detection system (IDS) that analyzes behavior anomalies in a causal reasoning system that has been in development for 7 years. This causality reasoning system infers trustworthiness of interacting actors based on their language-action features in an online environment. The technology has the ability to extract actors? language-action cues based on their online communication to establish dyadic attribution models of trustworthiness that can be used to identify potentially malicious behavior. Patterns of behavior are translated from language-action features. Language-action features feed the causality reasoning system where the trustworthiness of the social actor is analyzed and updated in a recursive Bayesian inference framework. The analysis from this dyadic attribution model has the potential for assessing threatening human disposition and intent based on information behavior. Using data metric analysis of anomalous behaviors, this technology can make sense of communication patterns that reflect human intent. Although generally imperceptible to human analysis, our research has proven that there are patterns of trustworthy behavior that can be recognized, just as there are patterns of deceptive behavior that can be recognized. Analysis of these patterns can be codified and programmed into a system that will process and extract subtle dispositional characteristics to derive outlier behavior. The research data to support this effort is collected from web-based interactive online games that emulate real-world scenarios in real-time. (http://isensoranalytics.com) What did we do? We performed over 100 interviews with market players to validate the value proposition of the technology and the pain points of potential customers. In this way, we were able to uncover the market potential for the product, which we think is significant but elusive due to limited funding. We identified a variety of market segments, and considered several distribution channels. We pushed the envelope to address the needs of markets that were peripheral to our initial marker segment, although we did not stretch our discovery process into these secondary markets. We maintained the focus of our discovery process by limiting it to the original focus of cybersecurity protection. We re-engineered the business model for the technology under development, and reached out to venture capitalists to seek investment. In general, we found VC?s to be interested but cautious, as our model was complicated—did not fit well into an elevator pitch. In addition, the inner workings of the technology could not be revealed so as to protect intellectual property. We held long discussions with potential clients and investors to identify a path forward, and the additional resources necessary to expand market viability. We met with programming consultants to scope out the effort required to complete a beta version of an automated next-generation intrusion detection system (IDS) that analyzes behavior anomalies to protect against outside attackers as well as insider threats. We met with legal counsel to scope out the limits of what we could and could not share with potential investors. We engaged with business development mentors and business technology owners to build conceptual infrastructure for next steps. We continue to focus on the ongoing research in anticipation of new milestones that will allow us to renew our efforts to create a business model upon the foundation of this critical research.
